results.title: Shearing Yaks (Tajik People)
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Explains how the yak herds, which stay high in the mountains, where it is cool, are brought down to the village for shearing. The wool is pounded by men with sticks, spun into yarn and kept until there is enough to make a carpet. Shows the Tajik people shearing yaks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Casting iron plow-shares
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
This film presents Tajik men of Afghanistan performing the several stages that shape, mould and cast, in wet sands, their iron plow-shares. It explains how over the centuries this ancient craft has achieved economy of action and perfect timing. No narration - traditional music accompaniament. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: The Tajik people: pottery making
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: This film shows the potters of the village of Kulala, who are Tajik tribesmen in the Afghanistan mountains. Native music is used instead of English commentary or subtitles, and the film shows the preparation of the clay and the production of pots. These are traded and sold throughout Afghanistan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Nuts to you
results.brief_description: Two Neanderthals, in order not to be exploited by “fast operators” learned to share the leftovers equally with each other, that adding two odd numbers gives an even number, that in adding even numbers the sum will always be an even number and finally, if a number can be divided by two it is an even number. No other credits available.

results.title: Array back when
results.brief_description: Breakfast to the Egyptian slaves, was a painstaking occupation. They could rarely get to work on time because the cook could not supply the required number of eggs to them. He had no system of organizing eggs into manageable number groups. A yo-yo salesman shows how grouping things into sets of twelve makes handling and counting more efficient. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Double trouble
results.creator_credit: Davidson Films and General Learning Corporation
results.brief_description: Crow and Lion, on an outer space trip, find a cell which begins to divide. The division continues until it approaches a crisis point: the two friends know the spaceship cannot contain the increasing volume of cells. A calculation has to be made to see how many days they can last. The computer read-out demonstrates a number pattern upon which a prediction can be made. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: 1,001 noughts
results.creator_credit: Lauren Woodby, Davidson Films and General Learning Corporation
results.brief_description: An ancient Arabian story poses a problem. Magic carpets are used as weapons of war and, in order to determine how many each enemy has, the king has to solve the multiplication problem that gives this information. Previewing recommended for follow-up work for teachers. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Beast of Ragoo Lagoon
results.brief_description: The Count is lost in his bathysphere in Ragoo lagoon. Crow and Dogberry have to trace and rescue him from the Beast who has swallowed the Count, vessel and all. This involves making up an area search, calculating oxygen supplies and getting oxygen to the Count. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Great Chimbu Pig Festival
results.creator_credit: Papua New Guinea. Dept. of Information and Extension Services
results.brief_description: Examines in detail the great festival of the Chimbu people of the Central Highlands of New Guinea. The festival is usually performed every five to eight years but Western influences have contributed to the seventeen year gap since the last ceremony. It is recommended that teachers preview this film before screening.

results.title: The Birders
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson, Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Winner of the 1976 Australian National Travel Association Jedda Award at the Australian Film Awards. The mutton bird industry of the Furneaux Islands (Cape Barren Island and Flinders Island) in Bass Strait is a little known and historic primary industry started by sealers more than 150 years ago. The film records the rugged life style of the small band of people involved in Mutton birding. Narrated by Ross Thompson and photographed by Kevin Anderson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
